abstract: A material that simulates the appearance of real-world objects.
overview:
## Overview

In RealityKit, a *material* is an object that defines the surface properties of a rendered 3D object. A Physically Based Rendering (PBR) material is a material that closely approximates the way light reflects off of real-world objects. Use [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicallyBasedMaterial] to create highly realistic-looking objects for your AR scenes.

Many of the properties for [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicallyBasedMaterial] provide the option to use more than one type of data to specify that property. You can set an object’s [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicallyBasedMaterial/baseColor-swift.property] using a specific color for the entire material, or you can use an image that UV-maps on to the entity.

[doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicallyBasedMaterial] includes all material properties supported by USDZ. On iOS 15 and later, RealityKit automatically uses [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicallyBasedMaterial] when importing an entity from a USDZ file.

For more information on using [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicallyBasedMaterial], see [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/applying-realistic-material-and-lighting-effects-to-entities].
rawMarkdown:
---
source: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/realitykit/physicallybasedmaterial
crawled: 2025-12-03T15:47:05Z
---

# PhysicallyBasedMaterial

**Structure**

A material that simulates the appearance of real-world objects.

## Declaration

```swift
struct PhysicallyBasedMaterial
```

## Overview

In RealityKit, a *material* is an object that defines the surface properties of a rendered 3D object. A Physically Based Rendering (PBR) material is a material that closely approximates the way light reflects off of real-world objects. Use [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicallyBasedMaterial] to create highly realistic-looking objects for your AR scenes.

Many of the properties for [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicallyBasedMaterial] provide the option to use more than one type of data to specify that property. You can set an object’s [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicallyBasedMaterial/baseColor-swift.property] using a specific color for the entire material, or you can use an image that UV-maps on to the entity.

[doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicallyBasedMaterial] includes all material properties supported by USDZ. On iOS 15 and later, RealityKit automatically uses [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicallyBasedMaterial] when importing an entity from a USDZ file.

For more information on using [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/PhysicallyBasedMaterial], see [doc://com.apple.RealityKit/documentation/RealityKit/applying-realistic-material-and-lighting-effects-to-entities].

## Creating a physically based material

- **init()**: Creates a physically based material.
- **init(program:)**

## Setting the core properties

- **baseColor**: The color of an entity unmodified by lighting.
- **roughness**: The amount the surface of the 3D object scatters reflected light.
- **metallic**: The reflectiveness of an entity.
- **normal**: The normal map for the entity.
- **ambientOcclusion**: The ambient occlusion values for a material.
- **specular**: The specular highlight applied to the entity.
- **clearcoat**: The transparent highlights that simulate a clear, shiny coating on an entity.
- **clearcoatRoughness**: The degree to which an entity’s clear, shiny coating scatters light to create soft highlights.
- **clearcoatNormal**: Waviness and imperfections for the top clearcoat.

## Configuring transparency and highlights

- **blending**: The transparency of an entity.
- **sheen**: The intensity of an entity’s sheen.

## Adding anisotropy

- **anisotropyLevel**: The degree to which an entity reflects light to create stretched or oblong highlights.
- **anisotropyAngle**: The angle at which the anisotropic direction of the material is oriented, influencing the reflection and appearance of surface highlights.

## Adding light emission

- **emissiveIntensity**: The intensity of light emitted by the entity.
- **emissiveColor**: The color of the light the entity emits.

## Modifying texture coordinates

- **textureCoordinateTransform**: A two-dimensional transformation to apply to the entity’s primary texture coordinates.
- **secondaryTextureCoordinateTransform**: A two-dimensional transformation to apply to the entity’s secondary texture coordinates.

## Culling unnecessary polygons

- **faceCulling**: A process in which the system specifies polygons to remove before rendering a mesh using this material.

## Setting depth testing properties

- **readsDepth**: A boolean value that determines whether this material performs the depth test by reading RealityKit’s depth buffer.
- **writesDepth**: A boolean value that determines whether this material writes its depth into RealityKit’s depth buffer.

## Setting shader properties

- **program**

## Classes

- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Program**: An object that represents the backing shader compilation required for physically based materials.

## Structures

- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.AmbientOcclusion**: An object that defines the ambient occlusion of an entity’s surface.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.AnisotropyAngle**: An object used to define a material’s anisotropy angle.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.AnisotropyLevel**: An object that defines the degree to which an entity reflects light to create stretched or oblong highlights.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.BaseColor**: An object that defines an entity’s base color.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Clearcoat**: An object that defines the intensity of an entity’s clear, shiny coating.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.ClearcoatNormal**: An object that defines the clearcoat normal map texture.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.ClearcoatRoughness**: An object that defines the degree to which an entity’s clear, shiny coating scatters light to create soft highlights.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.EmissiveColor**: An object that defines the color of the light an entity emits.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Metallic**: An object that defines the reflectiveness of an entity.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Normal**: An object that specifies an entity’s normal map.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Opacity**: An object that defines the opacity of an entity.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Roughness**: An object that defines the roughness of an entity’s surface.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.SheenColor**: An object that defines the color of an entity’s sheen.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Specular**: An object that defines the specular highlights of an entity.

## Instance Properties

- **opacityThreshold**: A threshold below which RealityKit ignores opacity.
- **triangleFillMode**: The object that controls how RealityKit draws triangles.

## Type Aliases

- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.FaceCulling**: An alias for the face culling object that’s appropriate for this material class.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Texture**: The texture type to use for materials of this class.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.TextureCoordinateTransform**: An alias for the texture coordinate transform that’s appropriate for this material class.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.TriangleFillMode**: An alias for the triangle fill mode object that’s appropriate for this material class.

## Enumerations

- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Blending**: The object that defines the transparency of an entity.

## Realistic materials

- **Applying realistic material and lighting effects to entities**: Enhance the appearance of objects in a RealityKit scene with Physically Based Rendering (PBR).
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.BaseColor**: An object that defines an entity’s base color.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Roughness**: An object that defines the roughness of an entity’s surface.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Metallic**: An object that defines the reflectiveness of an entity.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Normal**: An object that specifies an entity’s normal map.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Blending**: The object that defines the transparency of an entity.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.AmbientOcclusion**: An object that defines the ambient occlusion of an entity’s surface.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Specular**: An object that defines the specular highlights of an entity.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.SheenColor**: An object that defines the color of an entity’s sheen.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.Clearcoat**: An object that defines the intensity of an entity’s clear, shiny coating.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.ClearcoatRoughness**: An object that defines the degree to which an entity’s clear, shiny coating scatters light to create soft highlights.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.AnisotropyLevel**: An object that defines the degree to which an entity reflects light to create stretched or oblong highlights.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.AnisotropyAngle**: An object used to define a material’s anisotropy angle.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.EmissiveColor**: An object that defines the color of the light an entity emits.
- **PhysicallyBasedMaterial.TextureCoordinateTransform**: An alias for the texture coordinate transform that’s appropriate for this material class.

## Conforms To

- Material
